newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia waits for rate cut after good wage data.
newsitem.headline: Australia waits for rate cut after good wage data.

text.p: Australia's share market reached a record closing high on Thursday after the second piece of economic good news in two days cleared the way to an early cut in interest rates.
Official statistics showed that wage rises -- seen as the main obstacle to a rate cut -- rose only 3.5 percent in the year to August, at the low end of market forecasts.
After news on Wednesday that consumer inflation was down to a two-year low of 2.1 percent, economists predicted a rate cut to boost economic growth and reduce unemployment.
"It is hard to overstate how good these numbers are," Bankers Trust Australia senior economist Peter Munckton said.
"If the inflation numbers were a necessary condition for an easing, today's wages numbers were a sufficent condition," added Bruce Freeland, chief economist at Commonwealth Bank.
Australian markets have been getting increasingly excited about the possibility of a cut in the official interest rate, which was reduced to 7.0 percent in July.

Bond yields fell last month when Australian Treasurer Peter Costello remarked obscurely in the United States that Santa Claus (Father Christmas) could come "this year and next" -- taken as a hint that he expected a rapid rate cut.

But the Reserve Bank of Australia, which controls monetary policy, forced economists to revise their forecasts by warning that wage agreements were running too far ahead of inflation and productivity.
Costello welcomed Thursday's data, telling reporters that "low inflation and moderate wage growth always brings its own rewards" by easing pressure for high interest rates.

Industry groups were among those looking for a near-term rate cut, arguing that with low inflation achieved, a sluggish labour market and economy needed a helping hand. The RBA board next meets on November 5.

"Following on from the CPI (inflation data), there can be no doubt that interest rates should come down and they should come down now," Mark Paterson, chief executive of Australia's Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said in a statement.
Bond and stocks rallied on the wages data, as markets built in a 1996 rate cut.

The yield on 10-year bonds closed at 7.39 percent, their lowest close in over 2-1/2 years, while the main stock market index, the All Ordinaries index, rose more than one percent to register a record close of 2377.6.
The Australian dollar -- which would be less attractive to overseas investors if rates were lowered -- fell around 20 U.S. cents to just above US$0.7910.

Asked on Thursday whether Father Christmas could be on his way again, Costello replied: "Santa doesn't seem to come to adults as regularly as he does to children -- and you should not interpret the activities of Santa in a monetary sense."
